intro: Dialyanthera latialata, commonly known as the golden bellflower, is a herbaceous perennial native to South America. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its showy, bell-shaped yellow flowers that bloom in late spring. The plant typically grows to a height of about 30–60 centimeters and features hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in shaded to partially shaded woodland areas. The flowers attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies, contributing to its ecological significance.
